tags.name: append
tags.doc: Append a value to a list or other collection.
tags.synopsis: append a value to a list

values.name: values
values.doc: A sequence of values to append

tags.name: arg
tags.doc: Defines an argument for a [link commands]command[/link]. An [tag]arg[/tag] tag must appear within the [tag]signature[/tag] tag for a command.
tags.synopsis: add a positional argument to a command

nargs.name: nargs
nargs.doc: Number of arguments to be consumed

name.name: name
name.doc: Argument name (the variable when the command is execute)

tags.example:
<!-- Should appear within a <signature> tag -->
        <arg name="who" help="Who you want to greet">

tags.name: argument
tags.doc:
Defines an argument to a macro.

The text of this tag should document the purpose of the argument.
tags.synopsis: define an argument to a macro

check.name: check
check.doc: A boolean expression that the attribute must satisfy

tags.example:
<macro docname="average">
            <signature>
                <argument name="numbers" required="yes" check="len:numbers gt 0">
                    A list (or other sequence) of numbers
                </argument>
            </signature>
            <return value="sum:numbers / len:numbers" />
        </macro>

tags.name: ask
tags.doc:
Ask the user a yes / no question.

[alert WARNING]This tag should only be used in an interactive context, such as a [tag]command[/tag] tag.[/alert]
tags.example:
<ask dst="take_off">Would you like to take off?</ask>
        <echo if="take_off">Taking off!</echo>

tags.name: attempt
tags.doc:
Repeat a block of code if an exception is thrown. This is useful in situations where you are creating a database object
    with a random token, and you want to repeat the code if the random token happens to exist. The [c]wait[/c] attribute can set a timespan
    to wait between attempts, which may be appropriate for connecting to servers, for example.

    If an exception occurs, after [c]times[/c] attempts, then it will be thrown normally.

    [aside]Always set [c]times[/c] to a reasonable value. Programming errors could result in Moya getting stuck in a pointless loop.[/aside]
tags.synopsis: repeat a block until it is successful

wait.name: wait
wait.doc: Time to wait between syncs (default doesn't wait)

times.name: times
times.doc: Maximum number of times to repeat attempt block

tags.name: attribute
tags.doc: Defines an attribute in a [tag]tag[/tag], [tag]data-tag[/tag] or [tag]widget[/tag].
tags.synopsis: define an attribute in a custom tag
tags.example:
<datatag name="module">
            <doc>Define a top level admin module</doc>
            <signature>
                <attribute name="slug" required="yes" />
                <attribute name="title" required="yes" />
                <attribute name="description" required="yes" />
                <attribute name="content" type="elementref" required="no" />
            </signature>
        </datatag>

tags.name: bbcode
tags.doc: Add bbcode to content

tags.name: bool
tags.doc: Create a boolean (True or False value).
tags.example:
<bool dst="bool"/> <!-- False -->
        <bool dst="bool">yes</bool> <!-- True -->
        <bool dst="bool">no</bool> <!-- False -->
        <bool dst="bool" value="1"/> <!--True -->
        <bool dst="bool" value="0"/> <!-- False -->

tags.name: break
tags.doc: This tag will [i]break[/i] a loop such as [tag]while[/tag], [tag]for[/tag]. When Moya encounters this tag, it jumps to the statement after the loop.
tags.example:
<let crew="['John', 'Rygel', 'Scorpius', 'Aeryn']"/>
        <for src="crew" dst="character">
            <if test="character == 'Scorpius'">
                <echo>Taking off before Scorpius gets on board!</eco>
                <break>
            </if>
            <echo>${character} is on board</echo>
        </for>

tags.name: breakpoint
tags.doc: Stops the execute of Moya code and drops in to the debugger.
tags.example:
<!-- drop in to the debugger -->
        <breakpoint/>

        <for src="-100..100" dst="count">
            <!-- Conditional breakpoint with 'if' attribute -->
            <breakpoint if="count==0"/>
            <!-- This throws an exception when count is 0 -->
            <echo>${1/count}<echo>
        </for>

tags.name: cache-return
tags.doc:
Return a value from a cache, if it exists. Otherwise, execute the enclosed block.

This tag can be used to [i]memoize[/i] a [tag]macro[/tag] or other callable. Essentially, this means that if you call the macro a second time with the same parameters, it returns the previously calculated result. For macros that are slow to execute, this can result in significant speedups.

For example, the following code calculates the [url http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Factorial]factorial[/url] of a number:


[code xml]
<moya xmlns="http://moyaproject.com"
    xmlns:let="http://moyaproject.com/let">

    <macro docname="fact">
        <signature>
            <argument name="n"/>
        </signature>
        <cache-return key="n">
            <echo>calculating ${n}!</echo>
            <let f="1"/>
            <while test="n">
                <let f="f*n" n="n-1"/>
            </while>
            <return value="f"/>
        </cache-return>
    </macro>

    <macro docname="main">
        <call macro="fact" let:n="7" dst="result"/>
        <echo>${result}</echo>
        <call macro="fact" let:n="7" dst="result"/>
        <echo>${result}</echo>
        <call macro="fact" let:n="7" dst="result"/>
        <echo>${result}</echo>
    </macro>

</moya>
[/code]

If you run the above code, you will get the following output:

[code]
$ moya run cachereturn.xml
calculating 7!
5040
5040
5040
[/code]

The first time the [c]fact[/c] macro is called, Moya displays "calculating 7!" in the terminal. The second and third time, the text is [i]not[/i] displayed because the result is retrieved from the cache -- without the need to execute the code within [tag]cache-return[/tag].

local.name: local
local.doc: Should the value be cached for this tag only?

tags.name: call
tags.doc: Call a [link moyacode#macros]macro[/link].

lazy.name: lazy
lazy.doc: If True the result will be evaluated lazily (i.e. when next referenced)

tags.name: call-element
tags.doc:
Call a element object.

This tag calls an element retrieved with tags such as [tag]get-element[/tag]. For a general purpose call tag, see [tag]call[/tag].

tags.name: case
tags.doc:
Defines a case in a [tag]switch[/tag] tag.

If a [c]value[/c] attribute is given, it will be used as the comparison values, otherwise the tag text will be used.
tags.synopsis: define a case in a switch

value.name: value
value.doc: Value to compare in a switch

tags.name: catch
tags.doc: Catches any [link moyacode#exceptions]exceptions[/link] from the previous block.
tags.synopsis: catch exceptions from the previous block
tags.example:
<try>
    <echo>${1/0}</echo>  <!-- will throw a math exception -->
</try>
<catch exception="math.divistion-error">
    <echo>The try block threw an exception</echo>
</catch>

<!-- A <try> block is only necessary if there are multiple statements you want to catch exceptions for -->
<echo>${1/0}<echo>
<catch exception="math.division-error">
    <echo>You can't divide by zero!</echo>
</catch>

tags.name: choose
tags.doc: Pick a random element from a sequence.
tags.synopsis: choose a random value from a collection

tags.name: command
tags.doc:
Defines a command accessible from the command line. To invoke a command enter its full app name after 'moya'. For example:

    [code]$ moya testapp#cmd.hello World
Hello, World!
    [/code]

    You can also get a list of available commands for an application, by supplying the app name followed by #. For example:

    [code]$ moya testapp#[/code]

    See [doc commands] for more information.

synopsis.name: synopsis
synopsis.doc: Command synopsis, displayed when you list commands

tags.example:
<command libname="cmd.hello" sypopsis="Greet someone on the commandline">
            <signature>
                <arg name="who" help="Who you want to greet">
            </signature>
            <echo>Hello, ${who}!</echo>
        </command>

tags.name: common-mark
tags.doc:
Add markdown to content.

The output of this tag is similar to [tag]markdown[/tag], but uses [url http://commonmark.org/]CommonMark[/url] -- a standardized version of Markdown.

tags.name: content
tags.doc:
Begin a [link content]content[/link] definition.

Content is a high level description of a page.
tags.example:
<content libname="content.crew.manifest">
            <title>Crew Manifest</title>
            <section name="content">
                <for src="crew" dst="character">
                    <moya:crew character="character"/>
                </form>
            </section>
            <section name="footer">
                <markdown>Brought to you by **Moya**.</markdown>
            </section>
        </content>

tags.name: continue
tags.doc: When Moya encounters this tag in a loop, such as [tag]while[/tag] or [tag]for[/tag], it ignores the remaining code in the block and [i]continues[/i] to the next item in the loop.
tags.synopsis: skip remaining code in a loop
tags.example:
<let crew="['John', 'Rygel', 'Scorpius', 'Aeryn']"/>
        <for src="crew" dst="character">
            <if test="character == 'Scorpius'">
                <echo>Scorpius is not allowed on board!</eco>
                <continue/>
            </if>
            <echo>${character} is on board</echo>
        </for>

tags.name: copy
tags.doc: Copy a variable from one location to another

tags.name: css
tags.doc:
This content tag creates a [c]<style>[/c] element in html, with the enclosed text.

It is generally preferable to use [tag]include-css[/tag], but this tag can be useful to insert dynamically generated CSS.

section.name: section
section.doc: Section to add CSS tag to

tags.name: data-tag
tags.doc: Define a data tag. See [doc customtags].

undocumented.name: undocumented
undocumented.doc: Set to yes to disabled documentation for this tag

synopsis.name: synopsis
synopsis.doc: Short description of the data tag

tags.name: datetime
tags.doc:
Create a Moya [i]datetime[/i] object.

Datetime objects have the following properties:

[definitions]
    [define year]The year (integer)[/define]
    [define month]The month (integer) (1 is January)[/define]
    [define day]The day (integer)[/define]
    [define hour]The hours in the time[/define]
    [define minute]The number of minutes in the time[/define]
    [define second]The number of seconds in the time[/define]
    [define microseconds]The number of microseconds in the time[/define]
    [define isoformat]The date/time in [url http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601]ISO 8601[/url] format[/define]
    [define next_day]The date/time + 24 hours[/define]
    [define previous_day]The date/time - 24 hours[/define]
    [define year_start]January 1st at the beginning of the year[/define]
    [define day_start]The beginning of the day (midnight)[/define]
    [define next_year]January 1st of the next year[/define]
    [define next_month]First day of the next month[/define]
    [define next_day]The start of the next day[/define]
    [define previous_day]The start of the previous day[/define]
    [define previous_year]Jan 1st of the previous year[/define]
    [define previous_monthy]First date of the previous month[/define]
    [define days_in_month]Number of days in the current month[/define]
    [define epoch]Number of seconds since Jan 1st 1970[/define]
    [define html5_datatime]Date/Time in HTML5 format[/define]
    [define html5_data]Date in HTML5 format[/define]
    [define html_time]Time in HTML5 format[/define]
    [define utc]Date/Time in UTC timezone[/define]
    [define local]DateTime in local timezone (references [c].tz[/c])[/define]
[/definitions]
tags.example:
<datetime year="1974" month="7" day="5" dst="birthday" />
        <echo>Your birthday is ${localize:birthday}</echo>

tags.name: debug
tags.doc:
Executes a block only if Moya is in debug mode. You can enable debug mode the setting 'debug' under the project section. This tag is equivalent to the following:

[code xml]
<if test=".debug">
    <echo>Moya is in debug mode. Relax.</echo>
</if>
[/code]

[alert]Be careful to not do anything inside this tag that your project may depend on. It will not execute in a production environment![/alert]

tags.name: dec
tags.doc: Decrement (subtract 1 from) a value.

tags.name: dedent
tags.doc: Removes common whitespace from the start of lines.
tags.synopsis: remove common whitespace from a string
tags.example:
<dedent dst="text">
            This text will have the initial whitespace removed
                This will start with only 4 spaces
            Back to column 0
        </dedent>

tags.name: default-case
tags.doc: Defines the [i]default[/i] case in a [tag]switch[/tag] tag.

tags.name: default-markup
tags.doc: Use default markup if a value is None or missing
tags.synopsis: use default markup for missing values

tags.name: defer
tags.doc: Defer to a given element, such as a [tag]macro[/tag]. [i]Deferring[/i] to a macro is similar to calling it, but no new [i]scope[/i] is created. This means that the macro has access to the same variables where defer was called.
tags.example:
<macro docname="board">
            <echo>${character} is on board</echo>
        </macro>

        <macro docname="main">
            <let crew="['John', 'Rygel', 'Scorpius']"/>
            <for src="crew" dst="character">
                <defer to="board"/>
            </for>
        </macro>

tags.name: delete-cookie
tags.doc: Delete a previously set cookie.

tags.name: dict
tags.doc: Create a [i]dictionary[/i] object. A dictionary maps [i]keys[/i] on to [i]values[/i]. The keys and values are defined in the enclosing block, or via the [i]let map[/i].

default.name: default
default.doc: Default object to return if the key isn't in the dict

sequence.name: sequence
sequence.doc: Optional sequence of key / value pairs to initialize the dict

tags.example:
<dict dst="species">
            <str dst="Bibo">Hobbit</dst>
            <str dst="Gandalph">Wizard</dst>
        </dict>
        <!-- Alternatively -->
        <dict dst="species" let:Bilbo="Hobbit" let:Gandalph="Wizard" />
        <echo>Bilbo is a ${species['Bilbo']}</echo>

tags.name: doc
tags.doc: Write documentation for a widget or custom tag.
tags.example:
<widget name="post" template="post.html">
            <doc>Renders a single post</doc>
            <!-- widget code -->
        </widget>

tags.name: done
tags.doc: Exists the current callable immediately with no return value. Note, this is not equivalent to [tag]return[/tag] which returns [c]None[/c].
tags.synopsis: return from a macro or callable without any data

tags.name: echo
tags.doc: Write text to the console. This is typically used in commands or for debugging. Bear in mind that in a production environment there is no console.

header.name: header
header.doc: A list of headers for the table (if given)

obj.name: obj
obj.doc: If given, then the value of this expression will be written to the console

table.name: table
table.doc: A table to display. If given this value should be a list of lists.

tags.name: elif
tags.doc: Executes the enclosed block if a previous [tag]if[/tag] (or [tag]elif[/tag]) statement is false, and another condition is true.
tags.example:
<if test="hobbits == 0">
    <echo>There are no hobbits</echo>
</if>
<elif test="hobbits == 1">
    <echo>There is one hobbit</echo>
</elif>
<else>
    <echo>There are many hobbits</echo>
</else>

tags.name: else
tags.doc: Execute the enclosed block if a previous [tag]if[/tag] statement is false.
tags.synopsis: execute a block if the previous <if> statement is false
tags.example:
<if test="coffee==0">
    <echo>Get more coffee</echo>
</if>
<else>
    <echo>Have a cup of coffee</echo>
</else>

tags.name: enum
tags.doc:
Define and [i]enumeration[/i] object. An enumeration is a collection of text identifiers with an integer value. This tag should contain [tag]value[/tag] tags that define the values.

    It is generally preferably to use an enumeration over hard-coded numbers; it makes code easier to read and maintain.

start.name: start
start.doc: Starting ID if not specified in <enumvalue>

tags.example:
<enum libname="enum.jsonrpc.errors">
            <value id="1" label="not_logged_in" description="You must be logged in to do that" />
            <value label="invalid_score" description="Score must be -1, 0 or +1"/>
            <value label="unknown_link" description="Link object was not found"/>
        </enum>

tags.name: exit
tags.doc: Exit the current command. When Moya sees this tag it stops running the current command and returns an exit code. It will also write any enclosed text to the console.

tags.name: extend
tags.doc: Extend a sequence with values from another sequence.
tags.synopsis: add values from one sequence to another

tags.name: false
tags.doc: Creates a boolean with a value of False.

tags.name: filter
tags.doc:
Define a [i]filter[/i], which may be used in expressions.

Here's an example of a filter:

[code xml]
<filter name="repeat">
    <return-str>${str:value * count}</return-str>
</filter>
[/code]

And here is how you might use it in an expression:

[code xml]
<echo>${"beetlejuice "|repeat(count=3)}</echo>
[/code]

tags.name: filter-seq
tags.doc: Filter members of a collection which don't pass a condition.
tags.example:
<dict dst="crew">
            <dict let:name="john" let:species="human" />
            <dict let:name="rygel" let:species="hynerian" />
            <dict let:name="aeryn" let:species="peacekeeper" />
        </dict>
        <filter-seq src="items:crew dst="crew" test="species !- 'hyneria'"/>
        <!-- [{'name': 'john', 'species':'human'}, {'name':'aeryn', 'species':'peacemaker'}] -->

tags.name: find-element
tags.doc: Retrieve an element of a given type.

tags.name: find-elements
tags.doc: Retrieve information regarding elements of a given type.
tags.synopsis: retrieve information regarding elements of a given type

tags.name: fire
tags.doc:
Fire (broadcast) a signal. Additional data may be provided to the signal handlers, by setting values in the [i]let map[/i]. Signals may be [i]handlers[/i] with the [tag]handle[/tag] tag.

    Moya will catch and log any exceptions raised by the signal handler(s).

signal.name: signal
signal.doc: Signal name, should be in a dotted notation. Names with no dots are reserved by Moya.

sender.name: sender
sender.doc: Optional element associated with the signal.

tags.name: float
tags.doc: Set a float value

tags.name: for
tags.doc: Execute a block of code for each value in a sequence. This tag [i]iterates[/i] over a sequence, and executes the enclosed block for each value.

filter.name: filter
filter.doc: If given, then only those values which match this condition will cause the enclosed block to execute.

tags.example:
<for src="['John', 'Scorpius', 'Rygel']" dst="crew_member" filter="crew_member != 'Rygel'">
            <echo>${crew_member} is on board!</echo>
        </for>

tags.name: for-children
tags.doc: Loop for each child of an element
tags.synopsis: iterate over the children of an element

tags.name: forbidden
tags.doc: Respond to the request with a '403 forbidden' response

tags.name: get-children
tags.doc: Get the children of an element.

tags.name: get-data
tags.doc: Get all data from data tags.
tags.synopsis: get data from custom data tags

tags.name: get-data-item
tags.doc: Get a single data item.
tags.synopsis: get data from a single custom tag

tags.name: get-element
tags.doc: Retrieve information regarding an element.

tags.name: get-enum
tags.doc: Get an enumeration object (see [tag]enum[/tag]).

tags.name: get-locale
tags.doc: Get an object containing locale information

tags.name: get-tag-text
tags.doc: Get the XML text associated with the parent tag.
tags.synopsis: get text from the parent tag

tags.name: get-timezones
tags.doc: Get a list of common timezones.

tags.name: get-url
tags.doc: Get a named URL.

with.name: with
with.doc: Extract URL values from this object

base.name: base
base.doc: Base (protocol and domain) of the URL

query.name: query
query.doc: Mapping expression to use as a query string

tags.name: handle
tags.doc:
Handles a [i]signal[/i]. A signal is a way of broadcasting to other parts of the project that a particular event has occurred.

See [doc signals] for more information.

signal.name: signal
signal.doc: Signal name to handle. Multiple names may be specified to handle more than one signal.

sender.name: sender
sender.doc: Only handle the signal(s) if sent from this element.

tags.example:
<!-- Moya fires a number of signals itself, for various system events -->
        <handle signal="sys.startup">
            <log>This code executes on startup, prior to any requests</log>
        </handle>
        <!-- Handle a custom signal -->
        <handle signal="mordor.arrived">
            <log>${hobbit} has arrived in Mordor!</log>
        </handle>

tags.name: highlight
tags.doc: This tag is used by the Moya debug library to syntax highlight code (turning it into HTML in the process).

tags.name: html
tags.doc: Sets a variable to HTML.

tags.name: if
tags.doc: Conditional [i]IF[/i] tag, executes the enclosing block if a condition evaluates to [i]true[/i]. If the condition evaluates to [i]false[/i], the enclosing block is skipped. May be followed by [tag]else[/tag] or [tag]elif[/tag].
tags.synopsis: execute block if a condition is true

tags.name: if-get
tags.doc:
Executes the enclosing block if the current request is a GET request.

Basically a shorthand for:

[code xml]<if test=".request.method=='GET'">[/code]

May be followed by [tag]else[/tag] or [tag]elif[/tag].
tags.synopsis: exectute a block if this is a GET request

tags.name: if-post
tags.doc:
Executes the enclosing block if the current request is a POST request.

Basically a shorthand for:

[code xml]<if test=".request.method=='POST'">[/code]

May be followed by [tag]else[/tag] or [tag]elif[/tag].
tags.synopsis: execute a block if this is a POST request
tags.example:
<if-post>
    <!-- validate form -->
</if-post>
<else>
    <!-- not a post request -->
</else>

tags.name: import
tags.doc:
Import a library. Importing reads the XML associated with a library and makes it available to be installed as an application. This tag must appear within a [tag]server[/tag] tag.

    Libraries can be installed either from a Python module, or directly from a path. For example, this installs a library from a Python module:

    [code xml]
    <import py="moya.libs.auth"/>
    [/code]

    And this installs a library from a a relative path:

    [code xml]
    <import location="./local/sushishop/" />
    [/code]

    The [c]priority[/c] attribute is used when two element have the same element reference. This is typically used to override an element in another library. For example, let's say we have the following [tag]macro[/tag] in a library called [c]sushifinder.shop[/c], which calculate tax on a shopping cart:

    [code xml]
    <macro libname="macro.get_tax">
        <!-- calculate tax for an order-->
    </macro>
    [/code]

    We could replace this by defining the following in another library:

    [code xml]
    <macro libname="sushifinder.shop#macro.get_tax">
        <!-- custom tax calculator -->
    </macro>
    [/code]

    Note the use of a full element reference (including library name) in the [c]libname[/c] attribute. This tells Moya that the macro should go in a library other than the one it was declared in. If the code above is in a library with a higher priority then it will replace the macro in the [c]sushifinder.shop[/c] library.

    The [c]templatepriority[/c] is used when there are conflicting template paths. The template from the library with the highest priority wins. This value takes precedence over the [c]priority[/c] defined in [link library#lib-section]lib.ini[/link].

location.name: location
location.doc: A path to a Moya library

tags.name: inc
tags.doc: Increment (add 1 to) a value.

tags.name: include-css
tags.doc:
Add a CSS path to be included in the content. The list of paths will be added to a value called [c]include[/c] when the template is rendered. Here's an example:

[code xml]
<content libname="content.front" template="front.html">
    <include-css path="css/news.css" />
</content>
[/code]

The CSS paths can be rendered in a template as follows:

[code moyatemplate]
{% render include.css %}
[/code]

tags.name: include-js
tags.doc:
Like [tag]include-css[/tag], but inserts a link to a JS file.

The JS files may be inserted in to the template as follows:

[code moyatemplate]
{% render include.js %}
[/code]

This is equivalent to the following:

[code moyatemplate]
{%- for include in include.js %}
<script type="text/javascript" href="${include.path}"/>
{%- endfor %}
[/code]
tags.synopsis: include a JS file in content

tags.name: input
tags.doc:
Get data from the console.

[alert WARNING]This tag should only be used in an interactive context, such as a [tag]command[/tag] tag.[/alert]
tags.synopsis: ask the user for information in a command

default.name: default
default.doc: Value to use if response is empty

tags.name: inspect
tags.doc: Get an object which contains all the elements in the project.

tags.name: install
tags.doc: Installs an [i]application[/i]. An application is effectively an [i]instance[/i] of a library, with its own settings and serving content from unique URL(s). An [tag]install[/tag] tag should appear within a [tag]server[/tag] tag. A library must first be [i]imported[/i] (with [tag]import[/tag]) prior to installing.
tags.synopsis: create an application from a library

name.name: name
name.doc: Name of the application (must not contain a dot), e.g. "auth"

tags.name: int
tags.doc: Set an integer value.

tags.name: js
tags.doc:
Insert Javascript content.

    Here's an example:

    [code xml]
    <!-- must be inside a content definition -->
    <js>alert("Ready for takeoff!);</js>
    [/code]

    This would render the following:

    [code moyatemplate]
    <script type="text/javascript">
        alert("Ready for takeoff!);
    </script>
    [/code]

tags.name: json
tags.doc: Sets data from JSON (JavasSript Object Notation).

tags.name: let
tags.doc: Sets multiple variable from expressions.

tags.name: let-str
tags.doc: Like [tag]let[/tag] but sets variables as strings. Setting strings with [tag]let[/tag] can look a little clumsy because of the requirement to escape the text twice. [tag]let-str[/tag] treats attributes as strings and not expressions.

tags.name: link
tags.doc: Create a [i]link[/i] in the context. Similar to a symlink in the filesystem, a link creates a variable that references another value.
tags.example:
<str dst="foo">Hello</str>
        <link src="foo" dst="bar" />
        <str dst="bar">World</str>
        <echo>${foo}</bar> <!-- World -->
        <echo>${bar}</bar> <!-- World -->

tags.name: list
tags.doc: Creates a list. Any data items in the enclosed block are added to the list.

tags.name: log
tags.doc:
Write text to the logs. Every line of text can have a [i]level[/i] which indicates how significant the message is. Log levels can be filtered, so you only see relevant messages.

    You can control which log messages are written via [c]logging.ini[/c].
tags.example:
<log level="debug">This may help you track down errors</log>
        <log>Something worth knowing happened</log> <!-- default log level is "info" -->
        <log level="warning">Pay attention, this may be significant</log>
        <log level="error">Something quite alarming happened</log>
        <log level="fatal">Absolute disaster</log>

tags.name: log-debug
tags.doc: See [tag]log[/tag]

tags.name: log-error
tags.doc: See [tag]log[/tag]

tags.name: log-fatal
tags.doc: See [tag]log[/tag]

tags.name: log-info
tags.doc: See [tag]log[/tag]

tags.name: log-warn
tags.doc: See [tag]log[/tag]

tags.name: macro
tags.doc: Defines a [link moyacode#macros]macro[/link].
tags.synopsis: define a re-usable block of code

tags.name: make-token
tags.doc: Generates a token of random characters. This is useful for creating unique IDs for database objects.

tags.name: map
tags.doc: Create a list by mapping an expression on to a sequence
tags.synopsis: map an expression on to sequence

filter.name: filter
filter.doc: Skip item if this expression is false

tags.example:
<dict dst="crew">
            <dict let:name="john" let:species="human" />
            <dict let:name="rygel" let:species="hynerian" />
            <dict let:name="aeryn" let:species="peacekeeper" />
        </dict>
        <map src="crew" dst="manifest"
            expression="sub:'${title:name$} is ${species}'" />
        <!-- ['John is human', 'Rygen is hynerian', 'Aeryn is peacekeeper'] -->

tags.name: map-dict
tags.doc: Create a list of dictionaries from a sequence.

filter.name: filter
filter.doc: Skip item if this expression is false

tags.example:
<dict dst="crew">
            <dict let:name="john" let:species="human" />
            <dict let:name="rygel" let:species="hynerian" />
            <dict let:name="aeryn" let:species="peacekeeper" />
        </dict>
        <map-dict src="crew" dst="crew" let:name="title:name" let:human="species == 'human'"/>
        <!-- [{'name':John, 'human':yes}, {'name':Rygel, 'human':no}, {'name':'Aeryn',  'human':no}] -->

tags.name: markdown
tags.doc: Add markdown to content

tags.name: markup
tags.doc: Insert markup in to content

tags.name: max
tags.doc: Get the maximum value in a sequence.
tags.synopsis: get the maximum value in a sequence

tags.name: media-url
tags.doc: Get URL to media

tags.name: middleware
tags.doc: Add middleware to a mountpoint

methods.name: methods
methods.doc: A list of comma separated HTTP methods

tags.name: min
tags.doc: Get the minimum value in a sequence.
tags.synopsis: get the minimum value in a sequence

tags.name: mount
tags.doc: Mount a library.
tags.synopsis: mount a library on a given URL

tags.name: mountpoint
tags.doc:
A [i]mountpoint[/i] defines a collection of URL routes which map URLs on to moya code.

    An app will typically have at least one mountpoint with [c]name="main"[/c] (the default) which is used when the app is mounted. Moya will check each enclosed <url> in turn until it finds a route which matches the url.

    An app may contain multiple mountpoints, which can be [i]mounted[/i] separately.
tags.synopsis: define a collection of url routes

name.name: name
name.doc: Mountpoint name unique to the application

tags.name: moya
tags.doc: This is the root element for Moya files.

version.name: version
version.doc: version number of this Moya file (currently ignored, if supplied use "1.0")

tags.name: node
tags.doc:
Create a template node in a content definition. A node is essentially a reference to a template with associated data. Here's an example of a content definition containing a template node: [code xml]
${news}
[/code] Here's what newscontainer.html might look like. Note the use of [link templates#children]{% children %}[/link] which will render the content contained inside a node: [code moyatemplate]

The Latest News

{% children %}
[/code]
tags.synopsis: creates a template node in content

ifexists.name: ifexists
ifexists.doc: Skip if the template can not be found

withscope.name: withscope
withscope.doc: Is current context when rendering template

tags.name: none
tags.doc: Create a None value.

tags.name: not-found
tags.doc: Respond to the request with a '404 not found' response

tags.name: now
tags.doc: Create a datetime objects for the current time. The datetime is in UTC, use the [c]localize:[/c] modifier to display a time in the user's current timezone.

tags.name: odict
tags.doc: Like <dict> but creates an [i]ordered[/i] dictionary (maintains the order data was inserted)/
tags.example:
<dict dst="species">
            <str dst="Bibo">Hobbit</dst>
            <str dst="Gandalph">Wizard</dst>
        </dict>
        <!-- Alternatively -->
        <dict dst="species" let:Bilbo="Hobbit" let:Gandalph="Wizard" />
        <echo>Bilbo is a ${species['Bilbo']}</echo>

default.name: default
default.doc: Default object to return if the key isn't in the dict

sequence.name: sequence
sequence.doc: Optional sequence of key / value pairs to initialize the dict

tags.name: option
tags.doc:
Defines an [i]option[/i] for a [tag]command[/tag]. Options may be added to the command line when a command is invoked. The following is an example of how an option is used:

    [code]$ moya testapp#cmd.optiontest --hobbit="bilbo"[/code]

    An [tag]option[/tag] tag must appear within a [tag]signature[/tag] tag.
tags.synopsis: Add an option to a command
tags.example: <option name="hobbit" metavar="HOBBIT NAME" help="Your favorite hobbit" />

tags.name: page
tags.doc:
Chop a sequence in to a [i]page[/i].

    This breaks up a sequence in to a page, based on a page size and index. Useful for paginating search results.

tags.name: pop
tags.doc: Remove and return a value from a dictionary.
tags.synopsis: remove a value from a dictionary
tags.example:
<dict dst="species">
            <let john="human"/>
            <let scorpius="unknown"/>
        </dict>
        <pop src="species" key="scorpius" dst="scorpius_species"/>
        <echo>${scorpius_species}</echo> <!-- "unknown" -->

tags.name: preflight
tags.doc: A pre-flight check is used to detect potential problems, such as missing settings.

tags.name: profile-python
tags.doc: Profile Python code.

tags.name: progress
tags.doc:
Like a for loop but renders an ascii progress bar in the console, which will look something like the following:

    [code]
    [###        ] 30% working...
    [/code]

    This is useful for commands that may take some time to execute.

steps.name: steps
steps.doc: Number of steps in the sequence

tags.name: read-data
tags.doc:
Read and process a data file. The [c]path[/c] parameter may be absolute, or relative from the current application.

let's say we have a file, crew.txt in our [link library#data-section]data directory[/link], which is a text file with a list of names, one per line. For example:

[code]
Rygel
John
Scorpies
Ka D'Argo
[/code]

We can read the above file and process each line with the following:

[code xml]
<read-data format="text/plain" path="crew.txt" dst="crew" />
<for src="splitlines:crew" dst="characters">
    <echo>${character} is on board</echo>
</for>
[/code]

mimetype.name: mimetype
mimetype.doc: Mime Type of file (omit to guess based on extension)

path.name: path
path.doc: Path to data file in data filesystem

tags.name: redirect
tags.doc: Redirect to a mounted URL

query.name: query
query.doc: Mapping expression to use as a query string

code.name: code
code.doc: HTTP response code (use 301 for permanent redirect)

tags.name: redirect-to
tags.doc: Redirect to new location.

path.name: path
path.doc: New path portion of the url, may be relative

code.name: code
code.doc: HTTP response code (use 301 for permanent redirect)

query.name: query
query.doc: Mapping expression to use as a query string

tags.name: remove
tags.doc: Remove a value from a collection
tags.synopsis: remove a value from a collection

values.name: values
values.doc: A sequence of values to remove

tags.name: render
tags.doc: Render a [i]renderable[/i] object.

tags.name: render-all
tags.doc: Render a sequence of renderable objects.
tags.synopsis: render a sequence of renderable objects

tags.name: render-content
tags.doc: Render content

tags.name: render-template
tags.doc: Render a template
tags.synopsis: render a template and store the result

tags.name: repeat
tags.doc:
Repeat a block a set number of times, or indefinitely. You can leave a repeat loop prematurely with the [tag]break[/tag] tag.

    [alert Note]Be careful not to create infinite loops with this tag[/alert]

times.name: times
times.doc: Number of times to repeat (default is infinite)

tags.name: request
tags.doc: Make HTTP requests.

tags.name: request-get
tags.doc: Make a GET request (see [tag]request[/tag]).

tags.name: request-post
tags.doc: Make a POST request (see [tag]request[/tag]).

tags.name: response
tags.doc: Create a response object

tags.name: return
tags.doc:
Used in a callable block such as a [tag]macro[/tag] or [tag]view[/tag] to return data.

If you enclose any [i]data setter[/i] tag ([tag]int[/tag], [tag]str[/tag], [tag]list[/tag] etc.) in the return block, the result will be returned. For example, the following macro will return a list of three items:

[code xml]
<macro libname="get_crew">
    <return>
        <list>
            <str>John</str>
            <str>Scorpius</str>
            <str>Rygel</str>
        </list>
    </return>
</macro>
[/code]

Alternatively, you may use the [c]value[/c] attribute to return the result of an expression. The following code is equivalent to the above:

[code xml]
<macro libname="get_crew">
    <return value="['John', 'Scorpius', 'Rygel']" />
</macro>
[/code]
tags.synopsis: return data from a macro or other callable

tags.name: return-dict
tags.doc:
Shortcut to return a dictionary. For example, the following macro returns a dictionary:

[code xml]
<macro docname="get_character">
    <return>
        <dict>
            <str dst="rygel">Hynerian</str>
            <str dst="john">Human</str>
        </dict>
    </return>
</macro>
[/code]

We could shorten the above using the [tag]return-dict[/tag] as follows:

[code xml]
<macro docname="get_character">
    <return-dict>
        <str dst="rygel">Hynerian</str>
        <str dst="john">Human</str>
    </return-dict>
</macro>
[/code]

tags.name: return-false
tags.doc:
A shortcut to return False.

The following two lines are equivalent:

[code xml]
<return-false/>
<return value="no" />
[/code]

tags.name: return-scope
tags.doc:
Return values from the current scope.

This tag is useful in macros, widgets, and other callable tags where you want to return a number of values in a dictionary.

For example, the following will return a dictionary containing two keys:

[code xml]
<return-scope values="foo, bar"/>
[/code]

This is equivalent to the following:

[code xml]
<return value="{'foo': foo, 'bar': bar}"/>
[/code]

If you *don't* specify the [c]values[/c] attribute, Moya will read the values from the enclosed text (one key per line).
The following code is equivalent to the above:

[code xml]
<return-scope>
    foo
    bar
</return-scope>
[/code]
tags.synopsis: return values from the current scope

tags.name: return-str
tags.doc: A shortcut to returning a string.

tags.name: return-true
tags.doc:
A shortcut to return True.

The following two lines are equivalent:

[code xml]
<return-true/>
<return value="yes" />
[/code]

tags.name: rewrite
tags.doc:
This tag tells Moya to serve the content from a different named URL.

Note, that unlike [tag]redirect[/tag], this does not involve an extra request.
tags.synopsis: serve response from a different named URL

code.name: code
code.doc: HTTP response code (use 301 for permanent redirect)

query.name: query
query.doc: Mapping expression to use as a query string

tags.name: rewrite-to
tags.doc:
This tag tells Moya to serve the content from a different URL.

Note, that unlike [tag]redirect-to[/tag], this does not involve an extra request.
tags.synopsis: serve response from a different location

code.name: code
code.doc: HTTP response code (use 301 for permanent redirect)

query.name: query
query.doc: Mapping expression to use as a query string

path.name: path
path.doc: New path portion of the url, may be relative

tags.name: scope
tags.doc: Creates a new temporary [i]scope[/i] from an object.
tags.example:
<dict dst="species">
            <let john="human"/>
            <let rygel="hynerian"/>
        </dict>
        <scope object="species">
            John is a ${john}, Rygel is a ${rygel}
        </scope>

tags.name: scope-node
tags.doc:
Create a template node that uses the current scope as the template data.

This node is identical to [tag]node[/tag], with the [c]withscope[/c] attribute set to [c]yes[/c].
tags.synopsis: creates a template node using the current scope

withscope.name: withscope
withscope.doc: Is current context when rendering template

ifexists.name: ifexists
ifexists.doc: Skip if the template can not be found

tags.name: section
tags.doc:
Defines a section container for content. A [i]section[/i] is a top level container for content, and is used to break up the content in to function groups, which may be rendered independently. For example, here is a content definition with two sections; 'body' and 'sidebar': [code xml]
[/code] The template for the above content would render the sections with the [link templates#render]{% render %}[/link] template tag, For example: [code moyatemplate]

tags.name: serve
tags.doc: This tag serves a response object, which may be created with the [tag]response[/tag].
tags.example:
<url route="/test/">
            <response status="im_a_teapot" dst="teapot_response">
                Short and Stout
            </response>
            <serve response="teapot_response" />
        </url>

tags.name: serve-content
tags.doc: Render content and immediately serve it. Note that this tag will stop processing any more logic code.

tags.name: serve-file
tags.doc: Serve a static file.

ifexists.name: ifexists
ifexists.doc: Only serve a response if the file exists

tags.name: serve-json
tags.doc: Serve an object encoded as JSON

indent.name: indent
indent.doc: Indent to make JSON more readable

tags.name: serve-template
tags.doc: Render and serve a template

tags.name: server
tags.doc: Defines a server

tags.name: set
tags.doc: Create a [i]set[/i] object. A set is a container, where each item may only appears once. Any data items in the enclosed block are added to the set.
tags.example:
<list dst="hobbits">
            <str>Sam</str>
            <str>Bilbo</str>
            <str>Frodo</str>
            <str>Bilbo</str>
            <str>Sam</str>
        </list>
        <!-- Will display 3, because duplicates are removed -->
        <echo>There are ${len:hobbits} in the set.</echo>

tags.name: set-cookie
tags.doc: Set a new cookie.

maxage.name: maxage
maxage.doc: Max age of cookie (in seconds or as timespan)

tags.name: set-header
tags.doc: Add additional headers to the outgoing response.

tags.name: set-item
tags.doc: Set a value in a container
tags.synopsis: set an indexed value on a collection

tags.name: set-language
tags.doc: Set the current language

tags.name: set-locale
tags.doc: Switches the current locale

tags.name: signature
tags.doc:
Begins a list of attributes and arguments for a [tag]tag[/tag], [tag]data-tag[/tag], [tag]macro[/tag] or [tag]command[/tag].

In the case of tags, the signature should contain [tag]attribute[/tag] tags.
Macros expect [tag]argument[/tag] tags.
For a command, the signature should contain [tag]arg[/tag] and [tag]option[/tag] tags.
tags.synopsis: define the attributes / arguments to a tag / macro
tags.example:
<tag name="fib">
            <doc>Calculate the fibonacci sequence</doc>
            <signature>
                <attribute name="count" type="integer" />
            </signature>
            <let fib="[0, 1]"/>
            <repeat times="count - 2">
                <append value="fib[-1] + fib[-2]" dst="fib" />
            </repeat>
            <return value="fib" />
        </tag>

tags.name: sleep
tags.doc: Do nothing for a period of time

tags.name: slice
tags.doc: Slice a sequence of values (extract a range of indexed values).

tags.name: sort
tags.doc: Sort a sequence
tags.example:
<dict dst="crew">
            <dict let:name="John" let:species="human" />
            <dict let:name="Rygel" let:species="hynerian" />
            <dict let:name="Aeryn" let:species="peacekeeper" />
        </dict>
        <sort src="crew" dst="crew" key="lower:name" />

tags.name: str
tags.doc: Sets a string value to text contexts.
tags.example:
<str dst="hobbit">Sam</str>
<str dst="text"/> <!-- defaults to empty string -->

tags.name: sum
tags.doc: Sums a sequence of values together.

tags.name: switch
tags.doc:
Jump to a location with in a code block, based in an input value.

This tag takes a value ([c]on[/c]) and jumps to a [tag]case[/tag] in the enclosed block that has a matching value.
If there is no matching [tag]case[/tag], then execution will move to the enclosed [tag]default-case[/tag]. If no default case exists, the entire block is skipped.

This tag is useful in situations where a chain of [tag]if[/tag] and [tag]elif[/tag] tags would otherwise be used. Here's an example:

[code xml]
<switch on="species">
    <case>human</case>
    <echo>Humans come from Earth</echo>

    <case>hynerian</case>
    <echo>Hynerians come from Hyneria</echo>

    <default-case/>
    <echo>I have no idea where ${species}s come from</echo>
</switch>
[/code]

The above code is equivalent to the following:

[code xml]
<if test="species=='human'">
    <echo>Humans come from Earth</echo>
</if>
<elif test="species=='hynerian'">
    <echo>Hynerians come from Hyneria</echo>
</elif>
<else>
    <echo>I have no idea where ${species}s come from</echo>
</else>
[/code]

The [tag]switch[/tag] version is generally clearer, especially with a large number of conditions.

If the [c]on[/c] attribute is [i]not[/i] given, then the case's [c]if[/c] attribute is checked. Here's the previous example, implemented without the [c]on[/c] attribute:

[code xml]
<switch>
    <case if="species=="'human'"/>
    <echo>Humans come from Earth</echo>

    <case if="species=="'hynerian'"/>
    <echo>Hynerians come from Hyneria</echo>

    <default-case/>
    <echo>I have no idea where ${species}s come from</echo>
</switch>
[/code]

tags.name: tag
tags.doc:
Define a custom tag. A custom tag is in a callable tag that works like builtin logic tags. Here's an example of defining a custom tag:

[code xml]
<tag name="getstock">
    <doc>Get count of available stock</doc>
    <signature>
        <attribute name="product" />
    </signature>
    <db:get model="#Product.name == product" dst="product"/>
    <return value="product.count"/>
</tag>
[/code]

You may define a custom tag anywhere in a library. Once defined, the tag is available to any code that uses the appropriate namespace defined in [c]lib.ini[/c]. For example, if the above tag is defined in a library with an xml namespace of [c]http://moyaproject.com/sushifinder[/c], it could be invoked with the following file:

[code xml]
<moya xmlns:sushifinder="http://moyaproject.com/sushifinder">
    <macro name="main">
        <sushifinder:getstock product="tuna-roll" dst="count" />
        <echo>We have ${count} tuna rolls in stock.</echo>
    </macro>
</moya>
[/code]

Custom tags are preferred over macros when exposing functionality to other libraries.

undocumented.name: undocumented
undocumented.doc: Set to yes to disabled documentation for this tag

tags.name: throw
tags.doc:
Throw a Moya exception. An exception consists of a name in dotted notation with an optional message.

    Custom exceptions should be named to start with the [i]long name[/i] of the library. Moya reserves exceptions with a single dot for internal use. These [i]may[/i] be thrown if appropriate.
tags.example:
<try>
            <throw exception="middle.earth.cant" msg="One can't simply do that!"/>
        </try>
        <except exception="middle.earth.*" dst="error">
            <echo>Error: ${error.msg}</echo>
        </except>

default.name: default
default.doc: Default object to return if the key isn't in the dict

sequence.name: sequence
sequence.doc: Optional sequence of key / value pairs to initialize the dict

tags.name: timer
tags.doc: Time a block of code, and log the elapsed time. The log will display two time values; the first is the wall time, the second is [i]processor time[/i]. Processor time is more useful for profiling, as it doesn't include the time spent waiting on IO.

tags.name: title
tags.doc:
Set the title for content. This tag simply sets a value called [c]title[/c] on the context, which can be rendered in a templates. Here's an example:

    [code xml]
    <content libname="content.front" template="front.html">
        <title>Welcome!<title>
    </content>
    [/code]

    A reference to [c]title[/c] would appear somewhere in the template associated with the content. For example:

    [code moyatemplate]
    <html>
       <head>
           <title>${title}</title>
        </head>
        <body>
            {% render sections.body %}
        </body>
    </html>
    [/code]

tags.name: true
tags.doc: Creates a boolean with a value of True.

tags.name: try
tags.doc: Executes the enclosed block as part of a [tag]try[/tag][tag]catch[/tag] structure.
tags.example:
<try>
    <echo>${1/0}</echo>  <!-- will throw a math exception -->
</try>
<catch exception="*">
    <echo>The try block threw an exception</echo>
</catch>

tags.name: update
tags.doc: Update a dictionary (or other mapping collection) with keys and values from another dictionary.
tags.synopsis: add new values to a dictionary

tags.name: url
tags.doc: Add a URL route to a mountpoint.
tags.synopsis: add a url to a mountpoint

methods.name: methods
methods.doc: A list of comma separated HTTP methods

mount.name: mount
mount.doc: Mountpoint to mount on this url

handler.name: handler
handler.doc: A list of comma separated http status codes

mountpoint.name: mountpoint
mountpoint.doc: Name of the parent mount point

tags.name: value
tags.doc: Defines a single value in an enumeration object. Should be contained within an [tag]enum[/tag].

tags.name: var
tags.doc: Set a variable

tags.name: view
tags.doc: Define a view to handle a URL
tags.synopsis: define a view to handle a URL

withscope.name: withscope
withscope.doc: Use scope as template / content data?

tags.name: while
tags.doc:
Repeat a block of code while a condition is true, or a [tag]break[/tag] tag is reached.

    [alert Note]Be careful not to create an [i]infinite[/i] loop with this tag.[/alert]
tags.synopsis: repeat a block while a condition is true

tags.name: widget
tags.doc: Create a widget

undocumented.name: undocumented
undocumented.doc: Set to yes to disabled documentation for this tag

tags.name: widget-yield
tags.doc: Yield to a widget block
tags.synopsis: yield to code block in a widget

tags.name: with
tags.doc: Merge values with the current scope in the enclosed block. The values in the let map will persist only in the enclosed block.
tags.example:
<with let:hobbit="Sam">
    <echo>${hobbit} is my favorite hobbit.
</with>
<!-- 'hobbit' will no longer exist at this point -->
<echo if="missing:hobbit">Where is the hobbit?</echo>

tags.name: yield
tags.doc: Yield from a tag

data.namespace_doc: The default namespace used for most of Moya's tags.
